author: By Katie Rogers
title: Pete Buttigieg Joins the Parental Leave Debate: ‘This Is Work.’
description: “It’s one thing to believe something as a matter of policy,” Mr. Buttigieg said about taking paid time off. “It’s another to live it and see how much of a difference it could make.”
content: WASHINGTON — No gainfully employed person can predict what their workload will look like the moment their children arrive, or how taxing it will be to put those responsibilities aside and care for a newborn 24/7 — let alone two of them. For Pete Buttigieg, the transportation secretary, that moment came just as political stakes for his boss were rising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Finding a Keeper in the Course of ‘50 Throwaway Dates’
description: Eva Maria Theresa Janerus was just following the matchmaker’s orders when she met Gautam Mukunda in the summer of 2019. No other date could measure up.
content: Eva Maria Theresa Janerus, recently divorced, sought the help of a matchmaker in June 2019 to prepare her for the rigors of a return to the dating game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Money for Kindergartners, Spendable on College
description: New York City is giving every public school kindergartner $100 in a college savings account.
content: It’s Friday. We’ll look at college savings accounts that come with $100 for every kindergartner in public school in New York City — and why proponents say their value should be measured in more than dollars alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Elkin
title: Recognition, at Last, After Decades Decolonizing Art
description: Sutapa Biswas is the subject of two major exhibitions in Britain that explore the country’s imperial legacy.
content: LONDON — The British-Indian artist Sutapa Biswas has always found herself playing a confrontational role in the British art world, forcing conversations about empire and its legacies that the establishment preferred to evade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Brian Goldner, Hasbro Executive With Hollywood Vision, Dies at 58
description: He turned a traditional maker of toys and games into an entertainment company with its own TV and movie studio.
content: Brian Goldner, who transformed Hasbro, a traditional maker of toys and games, by rethinking its many brands as properties that could become films, television series and online games, died on Monday at his home in Barrington, R.I. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Wayward Zebra Found Dead in Illegal Snare Trap in Maryland
description: The state’s Natural Resources Police said they did not know who had set the illegal trap on private property in Upper Marlboro, about 20 miles southeast of Washington.
content: One of the wayward zebras that have been running freely across the backyards and roads of suburban Maryland since they escaped from a farm in late August has been found dead in an illegal snare trap, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Kiesling
title: When the Au Pair Helps With the Care of the Children and the Sex Life of the Parents
description: T.L. Toma’s second novel, “Look at Us,” follows a wealthy couple who embark on a sexual misadventure with their au pair.
content: LOOK AT USBy T.L. Toma
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Wall Street Sees a Record Deal Spree as a Reason for Optimism
description: Fees from advising corporate clients on mergers and other deals raised bottom lines across Wall Street. Bankers say it’s a good sign for the recovery.
content: The dealmakers at the nation’s biggest banks are the busiest they’ve ever been. Interest rates are low, private equity firms flush with cash are looking for promising investments, and companies are aggressively pursuing mergers at a breakneck pace.Wall Street banks announced blockbuster quarterly profits this week from a record wave of transactions that shows no signs of ebbing: Even in the face of surging inflation and shaky consumer sentiment, corporate clients are ready to deal — and bank leaders say that’s a reason to be optimistic about the economic recovery.“Whenever C.E.O. confidence is high, M&A activity increases,” David M. Solomon, Goldman Sachs’s chief executive, said in an interview Friday after the bank reported third-quarter earnings of $5.38 billion, surpassing analyst forecasts. “The world’s resettled a bit coming out of the pandemic, and that is now giving a lot of companies an opportunity to really take note of where they want to go.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Tim Arango
title: Complaints Against Texas’ Juvenile Prisons Include Violence and Sex Abuse
description: The extensive allegations present a portrait of an environment inside the state’s juvenile prisons that is rife with physical attacks.
content: SAN ANTONIO — In October 2019, a prison officer who worked at a juvenile detention center in Central Texas was charged with sexual assault and accused of forcing a boy in custody to perform oral sex on him in his cell. The incident came to light the day after the alleged crime, when the boy tried to kill himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Quebec Language Debate Spurs Eerie Sense of Déjà-Vu
description: For a Montreal-based Times correspondent, proposed language legislation brings back memories of the 1970s.
content: MONTREAL — When I go for a stroll in my Montreal neighborhood, the bourgeois-bohemian Plateau-Mont-Royal, I hear a Babel of languages — French, English, Arabic, Mandarin — and pass graffiti that playfully mixes English and French words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Global Allure of Crispy Chicken
description: The joys of eating fried chicken are universal, writes Yotam Ottolenghi, and his spin on lemon chicken is sure to satisfy.
content: LONDON — Fried chicken, crispy chicken, chicken schnitzel: Is there another dish so ubiquitous and yet, so particular? Everyone has one, yes, but everyone has their own. An “Around the World in 80 Dishes” cookbook could easily be filled with nothing but fried chicken recipes: Austrian schnitzel, Korean fried chicken, Italian pollo fritto, Japanese tonkatsu, chicken Milanese, Chinese gong bao, Senagalese chicken yassa, Southern fried chicken and so on. Fried chicken is beloved globally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: The Smoky Taste of Wok Hei, Without a Wok
description: Keeping culinary traditions going sometimes requires adapting to the realities of daily life.
content: My youngest child recently said to me, “I wish I was more Chinese.” We were eating mooncakes, trying to catch the bits of salted preserved egg yolk crumbling from the sticky-sweet lotus-seed filling. When I asked whether that sentiment applied to how we eat at home, I already knew the answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Texas Superintendent Apologizes After Official’s Holocaust Remarks
description: State lawmakers and the Anti-Defamation League condemned a school official’s advice to “make sure that if you have a book on the Holocaust, that you have one that has an opposing, that has other perspectives.”
content: A Texas school superintendent apologized to his district on Thursday after one of his top officials advised teachers that, if they have a book about the Holocaust in their classroom, they should give students access to a book from an “opposing” perspective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Knight
title: A Star of ‘Reservation Dogs’ Breaks Barriers
description: Paulina Alexis, an Indigenous Canadian actress, also appears in the next “Ghostbusters” movie.
content: Name: Paulina Alexis
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A Year Later, a Schoolteacher’s Beheading Still Haunts France
description: The killing of Samuel Paty by an 18-year-old Chechen refugee intensified debate over security and immigration, and prompted intense scrutiny of the French secular model.
content: PARIS — Most schools throughout France observed a minute of silence on Friday in remembrance of Samuel Paty, a teacher whose attempt to illustrate free speech to his students led to his beheading a year ago by an Islamist fanatic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan’s ‘Ghost Building’ Fire: a Death Trap for Dozens of Elderly
description: “I had no choice but to live here,” said one resident who survived a blaze that killed 46 of her neighbors and raised questions about lax safety standards.
content: KAOHSIUNG, Taiwan — Huang Chin-chih had heard disturbing stories about the “ghost building,” and the 58-year-old housemaid was not thrilled about moving in. She had heard about the gangs, the homeless people and the prostitution. She saw the drunk squatters, the dark corridors and the piles of garbage in the stairwells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Do Those Stress-Relieving Drinks Really Work?
description: A new crop of wellness beverages claim to help you feel more calm and relaxed, but some experts are skeptical that they can live up to the hype.
content: Wander down the beverage aisle of your local supermarket or bodega, and you might spot some dreamy-looking cans, in sherbet and pastel hues, promising to help you do something that seems in short supply of late: Relax. “Drink your meditation,” urges the label of one fruity, herbal tonic; “transcend stress, and open a portal to peace,” advertises another. One hemp-infused sparkling water claims it can help you feel “cool, calm, collected.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Soccer’s Problem With Silver Medals
description: It was notable when Spain’s players kept their runner-up awards after losing a final. It shouldn’t be.
content: In all the photographs, there is one constant. In some of the images, Spain’s players stare at the ground, disconsolate, chewing over their loss to France in the final of the Nations League. In others, they give interviews, lead-faced and faintly forlorn. In one, Luis Enrique, their coach, offers respectful applause for his team’s conquerors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Funding Fight Threatens Plan to Pump Billions Into Affordable Housing
description: A federal voucher program is at risk of being sharply scaled back as the White House seeks to slash its social policy package to appease two centrist senators.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Audrey Sylve, a retired bus driver, has spent 13 agonizing years on a waiting list for a federal voucher that would help cover rent for an apartment in one of America’s most expensive housing markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Leader of Apple activism movement says she was fired.
description: Janneke Parrish, who was a program manager for Apple Maps in Austin, Texas, was one of the two leaders of a group that called itself AppleToo.
content: A leader of an activist movement within Apple said she was fired by the company on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Monika Pronczuk
title: The view across Europe: Health passes in some countries, and no requirements in others.
description: Varying measures reflect domestic politics and potential opposition against such rules.
content: BRUSSELS — As Italy enforced Europe’s most stringent vaccine requirements on Friday, a patchwork of measures across the rest of the continent reflect those nations’ domestic politics and potential opposition against such measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Plant-Based Food Companies Face Critics: Environmental Advocates
description: Some analysts say they cannot determine if plant-based foods are more sustainable than meat because the companies are not transparent about their emissions.
content: Consumers and investors alike have gobbled up Beyond Meat’s burgers, sausage and chicken in recent years, thanks at least in part to the company’s message that its plant-based products are good for the environment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australian residents stranded overseas will be allowed to return to New South Wales.
description: New South Wales will become the first Australian state to allow fully vaccinated residents to return to the country without quarantining, starting next month, the authorities announced on Friday.
content: New South Wales will become the first Australian state to allow fully vaccinated residents to return to the country without quarantining, starting next month, the authorities announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: A Cute Neighbor and a Coincidence
description: And: How a pilot afraid of heights and an emergency room nurse not afraid of much dive into life.
content: If you meet a cute new neighbor and feel something long-dormant “crackle” inside of you, you might want to pay attention. In this week’s Modern Love essay, Amy Shearn explains how a sock that got lost in her building’s laundry led her to a new life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Testimony at Lev Parnas Trial Offers Peek at His Place in Trump’s Orbit
description: Among other things, Adam Laxalt, a U.S. Senate candidate in Nevada, described his suspicions about a donation to his run for governor in 2018.
content: Adam Laxalt was a Republican candidate for governor of Nevada in 2018 when he bumped into Rudolph W. Giuliani in a ballroom at the Trump International Hotel in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner and Adam Liptak
title: Justice Dept. to Ask Supreme Court to Block Texas’ Near-Total Abortion Ban as Legal Fights Continue
description: The Texas law prohibits most abortions after about six weeks, before many women are even aware they are pregnant.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration will ask the Supreme Court to block a Texas law that bans most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy while a challenge to it moves forward, a spokesman for the Justice Department said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: On a Fall Road Trip in Alaska, Prepare for the Unexpected
description: A five-day drive around the Kenai Peninsula reveals few crowds, affordable lodging and autumn colors. But your ability to be flexible will almost certainly be tested.
content: The tap beer ran low and boat tours were hit or miss. But lines were rare, as were the bottlenecks on roads threading mountainsides where yellow poplars and aspens, ablaze in the cool fall temperatures, radiated amid the evergreens. This is fall in Alaska, perhaps the most fleeting of seasons, when the weather can swing wildly day to day, from sunny, cloudless glory to six inches of wet snow.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Introducing the Ezra Klein Show Guest Hosts
description: A stellar lineup of guest hosts will be filling in for Ezra during his parental leave.
content: I’m going to be on paternity leave through the end of 2021, but the show’s not going dark. Far from it. We’ve got an all-star lineup of my brilliant colleagues and former guests sitting in the chair. Knowing what’s coming, I’m thrilled to get to listen in over these next few months, and I hope you will be too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler and Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Latest Scandal at Los Angeles City Hall
description: A councilman for South Los Angeles, Mark Ridley-Thomas, has been indicted on federal charges of taking bribes from a U.S.C. dean.
content: Like most big cities, Los Angeles has had its share of scandal at City Hall — some might say more than its share in the past few years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: A Sprawling Co-op at the Majestic Is Listed for $25 Million
description: The apartment, at 115 Central Park West, was home to George Malkemus, who popularized Manolo Blahnik footwear, and his husband and business partner, Anthony Yurgaitis.
content: The sprawling Upper West Side apartment where the footwear executive George Malkemus had lived with his husband and business partner, Anthony Yurgaitis, is coming to market for the first time in nearly two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: Adams Commits, With Few Details, to Keeping Gifted Program in Schools
description: Eric Adams, New York City’s likely next mayor, rebuked Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to scrap the current system as he prepares to leave office.
content: Eric Adams said on Friday that he would keep New York City’s elementary school gifted and talented program if, as expected, he wins the general election for mayor next month — a clear rebuke to Mayor Bill de Blasio, who recently announced plans to eliminate the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Brown
title: Why NASA Is Launching a Robotic Archaeologist Named Lucy
description: In a vast odyssey across the solar system, the mission will study asteroids known as Trojans that may contain secrets of how the planets ended up in their current orbits.
content: NASA is scheduled on Saturday to launch a probe toward clusters of asteroids along Jupiter’s orbital path. They’re known as the Trojan swarms, and they represent the final unexplored regions of asteroids in the solar system. The spacecraft, a deep-space robotic archaeologist named Lucy, will seek to answer pressing questions about the origins of the solar system, how the planets migrated to their current orbits and how life might have emerged on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Rising Rents Are Fueling Inflation, Posing Trouble for the Fed
description: Economic policymakers have said inflation will prove temporary, but rising rents may challenge that view and pressure Washington to react.
content: Terrell McCallum, a private wealth adviser in Dallas, spends a lot of time thinking about markets and interest rates. He knows that the Federal Reserve targets 2 percent annual price increases on average, so it was a shock when he learned that his rent would increase a whopping 10 percent this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Pandemics future and past.
content: This newsletter typically covers the here and now of the pandemic. But today I’m taking a step back to examine the future — and the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: A Fashionable Night at the Ballet
description: And, Carnegie Hall reopens with a black-tie gala and PEN America honors imprisoned writers.
content: The New York City Ballet held its fashion gala on Sept. 30 at Lincoln Center with new collaborations between choreographers and designers. Carnegie Hall reopened its doors on Oct. 6 with a concert, which featured Yannick Nézet-Séguin conducting the Philadelphia Orchestra, followed by dinner at Cipriani 42nd Street. And PEN America honored three imprisoned Iranian writers at its literary gala on Oct. 5 at the American Museum of Natural History.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: ‘Insecure’ Broke Ground by Embracing Imperfection
description: The show, which ends this season, depicted its characters as authentically flawed. “True representation is the ability to show your vulnerability,” said the co-creator and star Issa Rae.
content: “Insecure” begins its final season by looking backward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Films to Stream Now
description: The month’s picks include a contagion film, an ’80s throwback, an unnerving tale of siblings, a faux documentary and a slow-burn thriller.
content: Halloween is around the corner and already I’m up to my eye sockets in horror, whether it’s the marquee monster “Halloween Kills” or the daredevil Brooklyn Horror Film Festival, which runs through Oct. 21. So to maximize your movie-watching hours this witching season, three of this month’s picks clock in at no longer than 90 minutes. You’re welcome, boo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Don’t Blame Workers for Inflation
description: They are victims of rising prices, not the perpetrators.
content: Inflation is up and wages are up. Average hourly earnings for production and nonsupervisory workers rose 5.5 percent in the 12 months through September, which was the most since 1982, except for a few other months of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Bruel
title: Fright Lite
description: Four new picture books draw in young readers with ghosts, ghouls and vampires — not to scare them but to amuse them.
content: VAMPENGUINWritten and illustrated by Lucy Ruth Cummins
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asmaa al-Omar and Vivian Yee
title: Lebanon Observes Day of Mourning After Deadly Sectarian Clashes
description: The death toll rose to seven a day after gun battles between Christian and Shiite Muslim militias erupted amid tensions over an investigation into the port explosion last year.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lebanon observed a day of mourning on Friday, a day after lethal gun battles between Christian and Shiite Muslim militias erupted in the capital in a faint but dangerous echo of the 15-year civil war that devastated the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elle Cashin
title: Their Love Inspired Its Own Soundtrack
description: Indie country singer Alexandra Kay started dating Indiana Touchette when they were teens — and has documented their relationship’s highs and lows through her songs.
content: Indiana Touchette has inspired many songs for indie country singer Alexandra Kay. Her music has paid homage to their relationship, served as balm for heartbreak and even predicted their future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Michael Johnson, Sydney Harper, Mooj Zadie, Daniel Guillemette, Eric Krupke, Paige Cowett and Chris Wood
title: The Great Supply Chain Disruption
description: The supply chain crisis triggered by the pandemic was supposed to be over by now. It’s not.
content: Throughout the pandemic, businesses of all sizes have faced delays, product shortages and rising costs linked to disruptions in the global supply chain. Consumers have been confronted with an experience rare in modern times: no stock available, and no idea when it will come in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lois Smith Brady
title: Chasing Their Fears and Finding Each Other
description: Ben Lee, a recreational pilot and motocross racer, and Kerrie Knox, an avid camper and outdoorswoman, discovered every adventure was only more thrilling when together.
content: For their first date five years ago, Ben Lee took Kerrie Knox for a ride in his 1947 Beechcraft B35 Bonanza, flying in and out of a tiny airstrip near where she was living in Cleveland, Tenn. “One of the first things I noticed about Kerrie was just the excitement.” he said. “There was no fear.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: For Some Breast Cancer Survivors, October Is the Cruelest Month
description: Pink ribbons can be a tough reminder for many breast cancer survivors. Here’s how to make it easier.
content: There’s a quote from “Anne of Green Gables” that I’m already sick of hearing. “I’m so glad I live in a world where there are Octobers,” said Anne. “It would be terrible if we just skipped from September to November, wouldn’t it?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: David Sanford’s Music Has Flown Under the Radar. It Shouldn’t.
description: Few composers have broader stylistic reach. But on a new album, “A Prayer for Lester Bowie,” he makes it all cohere.
content: It’s not a big mystery why David Sanford’s energetic, well-crafted music has stayed mostly under the radar for the last three decades. “He’s not a self-promoter,” said the conductor Gil Rose, who brought out the first album devoted to Sanford’s orchestral music two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
title: Pandemic-stricken Thailand, aiming to revive tourism, reopens the cave a soccer team was trapped in.
description: For 18 days in 2018, Tham Luang Cave in northern Thailand was the scene of a tense rescue that captivated the world. Twelve young soccer players and their coach were trapped by rising floodwaters in a cavern deep inside the cave complex.
content: For 18 days in 2018, Tham Luang Cave in northern Thailand was the scene of a tense rescue that captivated the world. Twelve young soccer players and their coach were trapped by rising floodwaters in a cavern deep inside the cave complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy O'Neill
title: Love’s Perils, Trauma’s Wounds: New Story Collections
description: “The Ruin of Everything,” “Hao” and “Variations on the Body” explore fraught relationships and the long shadow of war.
content: THE RUIN OF EVERYTHINGBy Lara Stapleton123 pp. Paloma Press. Paper, $18.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera and Giovanni Russonello
title: Adele Returns With Power and Restraint, and 11 More New Songs
description: Hear new tracks by serpentwithfeet, Blackstarkids, Stromae and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Salt It Like You Mean It
description: Your chicken — and your pasta and your eggs and even your desserts — will thank you.
content: My kids’ babysitter asked me the other day how I make my chicken. The girls love it, she said — one of the most gratifying things you can hear when you cook for young kids, who are tiny, tyrannical critics. (Here are more ideas for what to feed them.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: The Velvet Underground Meets Its Match in Todd Haynes
description: In the director’s hands, music subjects are as much about their cultural moment as about their sound — a good description of the band led by Lou Reed.
content: Todd Haynes’s new documentary, “The Velvet Underground,” summons that band’s essence by being a feast for … the eyes. The screen is almost constantly split into self-contained images that are in conversation with each other, at times creating a dizzying sensory overload. Some of the most striking scenes use images shot by Andy Warhol, who was a crucial presence in the band’s life and art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Schumann at the Philharmonic. Robert, Too.
description: With a debuting pianist and conductor, a solo by Clara Schumann preceded works by her husband and Brahms.
content: Hasn’t the New York Philharmonic been through enough? Closed for a year and a half by the pandemic, and exiled from its home for renovations during its return season, the orchestra is now at the mercy of visa delays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Push to Improve Sex Ed in Australia Comes From 10,000 Miles Away
description: A grad student in London hoped to collect a few testimonies from teenage sexual assault victims for a petition to teach consent in schools. She got thousands.
content: LONDON — Not long ago, Chanel Contos was living the life of a typical graduate student, albeit a pandemic one: sleeping in late and attending online classes while enduring months of lockdown in her East London apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith and Erin Woo
title: Key takeaways from the sixth week of the Elizabeth Holmes trial.
description: Testimony addressed the question of whether Theranos was misleading and deceiving big corporations to get money.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Was Theranos a small start-up struggling to meet the demands of working with big, sophisticated and powerful corporations? Or was Elizabeth Holmes, the former chief executive of the blood testing company, misleading and deceiving those corporations to get money?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: ‘Succession’ returns and the sky is falling.
content: Welcome. I’ll admit I’m attracted to the new “dreamy-looking cans, in sherbet and pastel hues” of expensive wellness drinks proliferating in my local market’s beverage aisle. I bet they look good in a sun-bleached tableau on Instagram, but do they “transcend stress, and open a portal to peace”? Dani Blum looked into it, just in time for happy hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Reassuring Sign Before A Walk Down the Aisle
description: At the museum where Jamie Cooke and Dr. Joshua Zeiger were married, a neon sculpture on the outside wall read in all caps: “Everything is going to be alright.”
content: Jamie Antoinette Cooke and Dr. Joshua Ryan Zeiger figured they had been to at least 20 of the same social events while at Georgetown, starting with a welcome party in their freshman year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: ‘Electricity’ That Led to Love
description: Eight years ago, Chris Baker and John Federspiel exchanged smiles from across a crowded nightclub floor. And then they moved closer.
content: Chris Baker was with a group of friends at a nightclub in Hollywood, Calif., over the Thanksgiving weekend of 2013, when he spotted John Federspiel smiling at him from across a crowded dance floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: A lab in England issued about 43,000 false negatives on virus tests, U.K. says.
description: The mistake was described as an “isolated incident attributed to one laboratory,” in a statement released by the U.K. Health Security Agency on Friday.
content: An estimated 43,000 people in Britain were mistakenly informed that they had tested negative for the coronavirus after previously testing positive, the U.K. Health Security Agency said in a statement on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Katherine Rosman
title: N.F.L.’s Top Lawyer Had Cozy Relationship With Washington Team President
description: Jeff Pash, the league’s general counsel, brokered penalties, discussed a cheerleading scandal and received perks in emails with the former president of the Washington Football Team.
content: For nearly a decade, the president of the Washington Football Team sent emails to a friend in which he casually joked about Native Americans and racial and political diversity, griped about referees and league initiatives to improve player safety, and arranged tickets and perks for his correspondent. He also thanked the man for getting a fine lifted and for understanding the team’s thorniest troubles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Madigan, Michael Levenson and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Parkland School Shooting Suspect to Plead Guilty
description: The plea will include 17 counts of premeditated murder and 17 counts of attempted murder, a lawyer said, for one of the deadliest school shootings in U.S. history.
content: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — The former student who was accused of shooting and killing 17 people at his high school in Parkland, Fla., in 2018 plans to plead guilty to 17 counts of premeditated murder and 17 counts of attempted murder, one of his lawyers said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Terry McAuliffe’s Other Obstacle in Virginia Race: Democrats’ Apathy
description: Though the state is getting bluer, voters’ exhaustion is imperiling the former governor’s comeback attempt against his Republican rival, Glenn Youngkin.
content: RICHMOND, Va. — Terry McAuliffe doesn’t do subtext well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Biden Panel Wary of Expanding Supreme Court, but Open to Term Limits
description: Preliminary draft materials suggested that adding justices might be seen as a “partisan maneuver,” but said that an 18-year tenure merits “serious consideration.”
content: WASHINGTON — Proposals to expand the size of the Supreme Court are facing skepticism from some members of the commission that President Biden appointed to consider overhauling the federal judiciary. But there is something closer to a consensus that imposing term limits on the justices is worth exploring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: What I See in the Latest Blackface ‘Scandal’
description: Michigan’s campus cancelers aren’t snowflakes, they’re radicals.
content: At the University of Michigan recently, the music professor Bright Sheng — who’s had a superlative career as a composer, conductor and musician — wanted to share with his students how Giuseppe Verdi transformed Shakespeare’s “Othello” into the acclaimed opera “Otello.” That transformation is a rich and instructive topic in music composition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: What Does the Aspirin News Mean for Me?
description: New recommendations about aspirin, heart health and colon cancer have left many people confused. Here’s what you need to know.
content: For years, many doctors have recommended that people in their 50s start taking a low-dose aspirin every day to protect heart health and, more recently, to prevent colon cancer. So it was a shock this week when an independent panel made recommendations to curb aspirin use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: Dancing Cheek to Cheek Again: New York’s Tango Scene Rebounds
description: The pandemic was disastrous for tango. But milongas are thriving around the city now, capped by the return of Queer Tango Weekend.
content: The concept of social distancing simply does not exist in tango. This dance born in the working-class neighborhoods of Buenos Aires and Montevideo is about intimacy, touch and the closeness of the abrazo, or embrace. There is no distance between bodies; partners lean into each other, faces and chests touching, an arm wrapped around the other’s back, communicating through fingertips and subtle shifts in weight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ward Sutton
title: And You Thought the Sally Rooney Bucket Hats Were Ridiculous
description: Marketing a book is an art form, a delicate match of writer and approach. Ward Sutton imagines all the ways this could have gone wrong for famous authors in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Tiny Dollar
description: What do you think this image is saying?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: New in Paperback: ‘Memorial’ and ‘Singular Sensation’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE DAUGHTERS OF YALTA: The Churchills, Roosevelts, and Harrimans: A Story of Love and War, by Catherine Grace Katz. (Mariner, 432 pp., $18.99.) The “Little Three” (Sarah Churchill, Anna Roosevelt and Kathleen Harriman) who provided behind-the-scenes support at the 1945 summit with Stalin are, “in Katz’s telling … daughters Lear would envy,” Jennet Conant wrote in her review, while wondering what these shrewd women “might have achieved had they been allowed to do more than babysit for their famous fathers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: Big university endowments make billions in returns in a bumper year.
description: A big reason for the gains is investments with private equity firms, which in some years have received more in fees than endowments have paid out in tuition help.
content: University endowment managers, long criticized for the fees they pay to private equity firms and hedge funds, have something to show for it: eye-popping returns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Appeals Court Lets Texas Continue to Enforce Near-Total Abortion Ban
description: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit reaffirmed its reversal of a lower judge’s ruling that blocked the law while the federal courts weigh its constitutionality.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court said on Thursday that a near-total ban on abortions in Texas can remain in effect while the courts decide whether the law violates the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Katie Haun
description: A conversation about the future of crypto
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Katie Haun. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Governor Accuses Reporter of Hacking After Flaws in State Website Are Revealed
description: Gov. Mike Parson of Missouri has asked for a criminal investigation of a St. Louis Post-Dispatch reporter who told the state that a website revealed teachers’ Social Security numbers.
content: A reporter at The St. Louis Post-Dispatch this week alerted Missouri education officials that a state website that lists teachers’ names and certification status had a flaw: The page made the teachers’ Social Security numbers easily available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Concert Halls Are Back. But Visa Backlogs Are Keeping Musicians Out.
description: Visa delays are causing tumult in the classical music industry, leading to a wave of cancellations just as live performances are finally returning.
content: When the Seattle Symphony finally performed before a full audience last month for the first time in a year and half, something was missing: its music director, the Danish conductor Thomas Dausgaard, who could not get a visa to travel to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Just Like Their Manager, the Red Sox Keep Coming Back
description: Alex Cora spent a season in exile, and the Boston Red Sox sank to the A.L. East basement. With their manager back, the resilient Red Sox are in the A.L.C.S. These things are related.
content: Some year-long suspensions are better than others. The suspension Major League Baseball levied on Alex Cora, for example, could not have been imposed at a more convenient time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Penn Badgley Flexes New Dance Moves
description: The former “Gossip Girl” star returns in the third season of the Netflix thriller “You.”
content: “It feels good,” the actor Penn Badgley said on a recent Friday morning, in an echoing studio at the Mark Morris Dance Center in Brooklyn. “I’m clumsy as hell. But it feels good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Graham Jones
title: You’re Anxious. You’re Afraid. And I Have Just the Solution.
description: Dealing with horror on the screen and on the page can help you deal with horror in the real world.
content: These days, there’s a lot to be anxious about. There’s a lot to fear. There’s the environmental wreckage that’s increasingly evident around the world, the fragile state of our political systems, the mutating virus making the very air we breathe dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Lemire
title: Why Are the Boston Red Sox Singing ‘Dancing on My Own’?
description: A dance club anthem has become the unexpected soundtrack of a red-hot team. Credit (or blame) goes to a backup catcher.
content: BOSTON — The soundtrack of a baseball clubhouse tends to follow a predictable pattern, its beat sticking mostly with hip-hop, country, rock and Latin music. But when video clips emerged in recent weeks of the Boston Red Sox celebrating various playoff milestones, what stood out was the players’ enthusiasm — and full-throated singalong — to a melancholic club song from a Swedish pop star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘The Lehman Trilogy,’ a Vivid Tale of Profit and Pain
description: The play, tracing the rise and fall of the fabled financiers, finally opens on Broadway after successful runs in London and at the Park Avenue Armory.
content: Much of what happens in “The Lehman Trilogy” is invisible to the eye, which is not the way prestige drama usually works onstage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Today’s Must-Have Amenity? A Little Green Space.
description: Thanks to the pandemic, there’s a major shift in what New Yorkers consider luxury.
content: The move toward incorporating more outdoor spaces in luxury buildings was underway before the pandemic struck. But life in lockdown has made it a necessity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsea Garrison and Stella Tan
title: When the Taliban Aren’t the Only Enemy
description: What we heard from Afghan women.
content: The Daily strives to reveal a new idea in every episode we publish. Below, we go deeper on one from our show this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: ‘My Homeland’: A Poet’s Quest to Help a Family Flee Afghanistan
description: Zohra Saed, who teaches at the City University of New York, has rallied the literary community to help another poet and his family get to safety.
content: Zohra Saed was an infant when her family, ethnic Uzbeks, fled Afghanistan because of the Soviet-Afghan war, a conflict that killed many of her relatives. But she absorbed her parents’ stories as she grew up in Brooklyn, using them as she became a poet and editor who preserves the literature of Afghan writers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taimoor Shah and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Blast at Afghan Mosque Kills Dozens as Shiites Are Targeted Again
description: It was the second week in a row that attackers had struck a Shiite place of worship during Friday Prayer.
content: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Multiple Islamic State suicide bombers at a mosque in southern Afghanistan killed dozens of people and wounded dozens more during Friday Prayer, the second such attack on a Shiite place of worship on successive Fridays in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Goldman Sachs’s profit surges on record merger activity.
description: The Wall Street giant joined the country’s other big banks in beating analysts’ earnings expectations.
content: Goldman Sachs joined the rest of the country’s biggest banks in reporting profits that beat expectations, fueled by hot markets for stocks and corporate deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Chicago’s mayor and the city’s largest police union clash over vaccinations.
description: The city filed a complaint against the Fraternal Order of Police in Chicago on Friday, arguing that it was threatening an illegal strike.
content: A clash between Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago and the head of the city’s largest police union over coronavirus vaccinations intensified on Friday as the city filed a complaint against the union, arguing that it was threatening an illegal strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joey Roulette
title: Surprise Russian Thruster Firing Prompts Space Station Emergency
description: While the astronauts were said to not be in any danger, it was the second such incident since July.
content: The International Space Station was briefly tilted out of its normal position in orbit on Friday during a test firing of thrusters on one of Russia’s docked spacecraft.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Heather Murphy and Vjosa Isai
title: Vaccinated travelers from abroad, including Canadians with mixed doses, can enter the U.S. starting Nov. 8.
description: The date helps clarify the end to restrictions that had walled off tourists and relatives seeking to visit their families in the United States.
content: International travelers fully vaccinated against the coronavirus who have been barred from entering the United States during the pandemic will be able to enter the country on Nov. 8, according to a White House official, marking an end to restrictions that had walled off tourists and relatives seeking to visit their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Season 3: What to Remember Before You Watch
description: Two years have passed since Season 2 ended, and the alliances and schemes were as layered as an insult from Roman Roy. Here’s a quick catch-up guide.
content: Because of the pandemic, the HBO drama “Succession” has been on hiatus for two years. People who had never seen “Succession” when it racked up seven Emmys last year had plenty of time to catch up ahead of Season 3, which premieres on Sunday. But fans who haven’t seen an episode since the Season 2 finale aired — back in October 2019! — could maybe use a refresher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: The Unvaccinated May Not Be Who You Think
description: Science can find a cure for our diseases, but not for our societal ills.
content: Back when a viral pandemic killing millions around the world was just the plot of a scary movie, the film “Contagion” was lauded for how accurately it depicted the way such an outbreak would occur.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Farewell to a Ballerina With Borscht Belt Humor and ‘Legs of Life’
description: Maria Kowroski, the reigning principal of New York City Ballet and the last company member to have worked with Jerome Robbins, takes her final bow.
content: Maria Kowroski is a ballerina nearing the finish line. She is also a ballerina who laughs even when she’s in pain — and as her dancing days wind down, she is in pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Meet Me in My Office, in Men’s Underwear on 5
description: Department stores have failed; co-working spaces have foundered. Does combining the two make sense?
content: For 10 years beginning in 1945, the architect George Nelson served as the design director at Herman Miller, the iconic furniture producer, where he came to believe that the modern office should resemble “a daytime living room.’’ The geography of the conventional white-collar workplace bred stress and distraction, the thinking went, and as a result, hindered creativity and collaboration. It would take decades and significant advances in technology for corporate ideology to catch up with Nelson’s vision. And then, at some point in the 21st century, it surpassed what he had imagined, in strange ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Gebeloff
title: A Racial Disparity in Schizophrenia Diagnoses in Nursing Homes
description: Diagnoses for the disorder have soared in the past decade, driven in part by a loophole in regulations. A new study shows the impact has been more severe for Black Americans.
content: The share of American nursing home residents who are recorded as having schizophrenia has soared over the past decade. As The New York Times reported last month, the change is driven in part by a surge of questionable diagnoses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Faulty Studs Led to Mexico City Metro Collapse, Attorney General Says
description: A monthslong investigation by city authorities supports the central findings of a New York Times investigation, which had uncovered a series of fatal construction flaws.
content: MEXICO CITY — Poorly placed studs, clear design flaws and deficient welding led to a collapse in the capital’s metro system last spring that left 26 people dead and scores injured, the attorney general for Mexico City said Thursday in releasing the results of a monthslong investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Crypto Optimist Meets a Crypto Skeptic
description: Katie Haun and I discuss the future cryptocurrency could create.
content: I’ve been wanting to explore the world crypto and blockchain technologies could build on the show for a while. In certain ways, I’m an optimist: I think these technologies matter, and many of them will work. In other ways, I’m a skeptic: I’m unconvinced that their wide adoption will lead to the glittering, decentralized digital world that many crypto proponents imagine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: Rikers Death Pushes Toll in N.Y.C. Jails to 13 This Year
description: The man who died contracted the coronavirus while awaiting trial on weapons charges after being unable to post $100,000 bail, his lawyer said.
content: A Bronx man who was being held at the Rikers Island jail complex died on Friday after, his lawyer said, he contracted the coronavirus — the 13th death in custody during an especially deadly year in New York City’s jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Man Whose Attack on Ex-Wife Was Livestreamed Gets Death Penalty in China
description: The case riveted the public’s attention in China and spotlighted the patchy enforcement of the country’s law against domestic violence.
content: A court in China gave the death penalty to a man who murdered his ex-wife while she was livestreaming, a case that shocked the country and ignited calls for better safeguards against domestic abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A Blackface ‘Othello’ Shocks, and a Professor Steps Back From Class
description: Students objected after the composer Bright Sheng showed the 1965 film of Laurence Olivier’s “Othello” to his class at the University of Michigan.
content: It was supposed to be an opportunity for music students at the University of Michigan to learn about the process of adapting a classic literary text into an opera from one of the music school’s most celebrated professors, the composer Bright Sheng.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can I Wear a Ponytail to Work Without Looking Like a Kid?
description: A teacher would prefer to not look like one of her students — or a character from “Grease.”
content: The ponytail has been a default hairdo ever since Ancient Greece and 1600 B.C.E., where the look was immortalized at the Palace of Knossos on Crete in the fresco “Ladies in Blue.” A look possessed of multiple personalities and social signifiers, the ponytail can seem like the simplest of possible ’dos while also adapting to changes in culture and social mores — and it has done so throughout history and for both men and women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The state of the pandemic in the U.S.
content: After a brutal summer surge, driven by the Delta variant, the coronavirus is again in retreat in the U.S. weBut given how many Americans remain unvaccinated, it is too soon to abandon basic precautions, scientists warn. The potential emergence of a new variant remains a wild card, while the protection afforded by vaccination could start to wane more substantially.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Johnson & Johnson Subsidiary Seeks Bankruptcy Protection to Handle Talc Product Claims
description: The company said the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing was intended to resolve current and future claims that its products cause cancer.
content: Johnson & Johnson announced on Thursday that a subsidiary that it recently created to manage claims that assert that its talc-based products caused cancer had filed for bankruptcy protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Harvard’s Investment Report Card
description: Big college endowments had a bumper year.
content: University endowment managers, long criticized for the fees they pay out to private equity firms and hedge funds, have something to show for it: eye-popping returns. Yesterday, M.I.T. reported that its endowment had gained 56 percent in its most recent fiscal year, which ended in June. Yale also published its latest returns yesterday, with its endowment up 40 percent over the same period, its third-highest annual return since 1970. Dartmouth posted a return of nearly 47 percent. Duke reported a 56 percent return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Power of ‘Nobody Knows’
description: I beseech you, think it possible you may be mistaken.
content: What’s happening to inflation? We know, of course, what the current numbers say: Inflation is high right now, although not 1970s high. But is this a blip or the beginning of a longer-term problem? Economists are deeply divided. I’m basically for the former, on what has come to be known as Team Transitory, but I might be wrong — and the data are sufficiently ambiguous that both sides can claim that the evidence supports their take.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: A Home Built for the Next Pandemic
description: A new Covid concept house pitches itself as empowering and feminist. Is it?
content: A collaboration between three businesswomen, built by Garman Homes, is betting that Covid will change the way we design, buy and live in our homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Isn’t Threatened by Trump’s Latest Stunt
description: This week, Donald Trump said Republicans should not be voting in the 2022 or 2024 elections. “Wow, he’s been out of office so long, he’s forgotten how threats work,” Seth Meyers said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Beyond Chucky: Frightening Alternatives for Halloween TV
description: If this Halloween season’s brand-name horror retreads leave you cold, here are some frightening alternatives.
content: The approach of Halloween brings an influx of horror to television and streaming, and this year the offerings have a classic appeal: reboots of “Chucky” on Syfy and USA, “Day of the Dead” on Syfy and of “I Know What You Did Last Summer” on Amazon Prime Video. But if the familiar delights of those franchises — and the campiness or melodrama that come with them — don’t appeal to you, here are a few recent or coming series that are scary with a difference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Gary Paulsen, Author of Young-Adult Adventures, Dies at 82
description: His 200 books, among them “Hatchet” and “Dogsong,” inspired generations with their tales of exploration, survival and the bloody reality of the natural world.
content: Gary Paulsen, a prolific writer whose young-adult novels like “Hatchet” and Dogsong” inspired generations of would-be adventurers with tales of survival, exploration and nature red in tooth and claw, died on Wednesday at his home in Tularosa, N.M. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: In Battle of Rivals, the Dodgers Outlast the Giants to Reach the N.L.C.S.
description: A late single by Cody Bellinger was the difference in a hard-fought pitching matchup between 109-win teams.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — When the chase was finished and the Los Angeles Dodgers had finally caught the San Francisco Giants, when their blue uniforms were drenched with champagne and their frayed nerves were slowly coming back together, Max Scherzer could only shake his head and marvel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ‘The Only Exit’: Where Soldiers Are Dying After Sexual Assaults
description: The death of a woman in South Korea’s air force has rekindled outrage over the country’s armed forces, long criticized for abusing and discriminating​ against women.
content: SEOUL — ​ The soldiers were driving back to the South Korean air force base after dinner and drinks on March 2. In the back seat, Master Sgt. Lee Ye-ram could be heard repeatedly begging her male colleague​, Master Sgt. Chang Dong-hoon, to stop sexually assaulting her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Retail sales were lifted in September by spending and higher prices.
description: The 0.7% increase was better than expected. Rising consumer prices were a factor, but economists said the results showed Americans wanted to get out and shop.
content: Retail sales rose unexpectedly in September, as American consumers shook off fast-rising prices, shortages of goods, and the Delta variant outbreak in many parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: For the Giants, a Rapid Ascent, a Hard Fall and Hopes of a Rematch
description: San Francisco had a 109-win season dissolve at the hands of a bitter rival, but they still view their future as bright. “This won’t be the last time we play them in the playoffs.”
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The three-time champion wound his way through the tunnel outside the San Francisco Giants’ clubhouse after the most intense nine innings of this baseball season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Victoria Petersen
title: When Outdoor Diners and Homeless People Meet, Restaurants Try to Cope
description: As homelessness grows in New York City, owners seek ways to defuse conflicts between panhandlers and their customers and employees, from hiring guards to feeding the hungry.
content: When Stephen Werther, an owner and the chef of the West Village restaurant and market Suprema Provisions, opened his business for outdoor dining in the summer of 2020, he noticed people aggressively panhandling his customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Key to Biden’s Climate Agenda Likely to Be Cut Because of Manchin Opposition
description: The West Virginia Democrat told the White House he is firmly against a clean electricity program that is the muscle behind the president’s plan to battle climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — The most powerful part of President Biden’s climate agenda — a program to rapidly replace the nation’s coal- and gas-fired power plants with wind, solar and nuclear energy — will likely be dropped from the massive budget bill pending in Congress, according to congressional staffers and lobbyists familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Abramson
title: This Justice Is Taking Over the Supreme Court, and He Won’t Be Alone
description: With conservative justices in the majority, the court seems to be reshaping itself in Justice Thomas’s image.
content: After he took his seat on the U.S. Supreme Court 30 years ago this month, Justice Clarence Thomas assured his law clerks, “I ain’t evolving.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Shearn
title: How a Missing Sock Changed My Life
description: Not the sock itself, but a note attached to the sock. (Actually, the guy who wrote the note.)
content: Nearly five years ago, I found a stray sock in my building’s lobby with a note affixed to it that read: “This guy got separated from his family and I found him wandering scared and lost in my own laundry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Finneas, a Pop Star’s Secret Weapon, Strides Into the Spotlight
description: He’s won eight Grammys alongside his sister, Billie Eilish, and worked with some of the genre’s biggest stars. Now the 24-year-old musician is arriving as a solo artist with “Optimist.”
content: LOS ANGELES — There’s a ghoul hanging around Finneas’s house. A dark shadow spinning past the window of his otherwise sunny and calm music studio. “The way it moves, it catches your eye at the wrong time,” he said. It spooks him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: Toyota will cut production in November 15 percent amid pandemic chip shortages.
description: The automaker had initially planned to produce a million vehicles in November, but now projects it will make 850,000 to 900,000.
content: Toyota said on Friday that it would cut November production targets at home and abroad by as much as 15 percent as the pandemic and a global semiconductor shortage have made it difficult for the Japanese automaker to meet its short-term manufacturing goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Shareholder Democracy Is Getting Bigger Trial Runs
description: Fund investors are rarely asked what concerns them or how they’d vote. But now, several measures aim to do that. Still, it’s just a start, our columnist says.
content: When you buy shares of a publicly traded company, you’re a part owner and, in theory, have a right to vote on some important matters that come before that company’s board of directors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Navigating the Dave Chappelle Fracas at Netflix
description: The comedian needs to just move on.
content: In a recent live onstage interview with me, the Netflix co-C.E.O. Ted Sarandos said a lot of things about a lot of things, including the streaming business, the state of content production and his leadership style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: The Visionary Community of the Harlem Y.M.C.A.
description: In the early 20th century, the building became a meeting place for many of the writers, artists, actors and activists who defined a new and vibrant Black culture.
content: THE MOST PROMINENT building on West 135th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem is not an elaborate church or a stately apartment building but the 90-year-old Y.M.C.A. But despite its bulk, the edifice — with its brick facade, 14-story tower and tall sign with the letters “Y.M.C.A.” blazing in red neon each night — can be easy to overlook: It’s been a mainstay of the neighborhood for so long that its residents sometimes forget to notice it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Is It Time for Kyrsten Sinema to Leave the Democratic Party?
description: The Arizona senator is, at heart, a Democrat of convenience and expediency. She could well break up with the party — before it breaks up with her.
content: Despite her flamboyant persona — the Crayola-colored wigs, the edgy outfits, the in-your-face bling — Senator Kyrsten Sinema rarely talks smack about other lawmakers. But when Democratic leaders delayed a promised House vote on the bipartisan infrastructure bill that the Arizona Democrat had helped spearhead, she let loose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia, Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Longtime U.K. Lawmaker Stabbed to Death in Attack Labeled Terrorism
description: David Amess, a Conservative member of Parliament, was holding a meeting in his constituency at the time. He is the second politician killed in an attack in just over five years.
content: LEIGH-ON-SEA, England — For the second time in little more than five years, a British lawmaker meeting with constituents was killed in full view of the public, this time in a genteel seaside town, where the victim, a Conservative Party member of Parliament, was fatally stabbed on Friday inside a church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Sheinbaum
title: A ‘Summer House’ Wedding Five Seasons in the Making
description: Not a pandemic nor a shared canned-cocktail business nor a Bravo reality series could tear apart Amanda Batula and Kyle Cooke.
content: On a Thursday in August 2015 — almost a year before Bravo TV cameras started filming the reality show “Summer House” — Amanda Batula and Kyle Cooke were guests at a penthouse apartment in Manhattan’s NoLIta neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Match Made in Group Meditation
description: Among the Central Park turtles (and about 50 other people), Danielle Casey Bloch and Daniel Bloch Jeydel learned each other’s names. He needed to know more.
content: In September 2018, participants in a Yom Kippur meditation began to arrive in front of the Turtle Pond in Central Park. Daniel Bloch Jeydel introduced himself to Danielle Casey Bloch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: The Birkin Bag Gets an Update
description: Thanks to a new puzzle-like design, the iconic and much-coveted Hermès carryall can now be worn three different ways.
content: In 1984, the English actress Jane Birkin hopped on an Air France flight from Paris to London. As she hurried down the aisle, the contents of her handbag spilled to the floor. Luckily, she happened to be sitting next to Jean-Louis Dumas, then the executive chairman of Hermès, and somewhere over the English Channel, the two came up with the design for her now-iconic namesake carryall, which they sketched out together while on board. The Birkin would be bigger than the Kelly, but smaller than the Haut à Courroies, and contain interior pockets for storing belongings, as well as a burnished flap top with the house’s signature saddle stitching and a turn-lock swivel clasp. It became the most coveted of Hermès’s handbags, with yearslong wait lists and limited editions in numerous colorways and skins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italy Puts in Force Tough New Law Requiring Workers to Test or Vaccinate

title: At Her Home in Suffolk, Olivia Laing Finds Fresh Inspiration
description: For the author, the process of creating and tending her garden in the English countryside is akin to that of shaping a book.
content: A GARDEN BURSTING through the hard, cold ground in spring is a metaphor for resilience that few writers — especially those who are also gardeners — can resist. Mid-pandemic, the English cultural critic Olivia Laing, 44, moved into a Grade II-listed house on a third of an acre in the East Anglia county of Suffolk, two hours northeast of London. Tending the perennial beds and clipping the yew hedges at the house — sometimes still in pajamas or late into the evening — she often finds herself thinking about the death-and-resurrection cycles that have taken place there through the centuries, and of the literary gardeners who have shaped her and her work. In her mind, they are as alive as the white roses that climb her new home’s 18th-century white-plastered brick facade.
